===Protests===
===Protests===
  +
[[File:Yemeni Protests 4-Apr-2011 P01.JPG|thumb|Protests in [[Sanaâa]].]]
  +
{{External media
  +
| video1 = {{YouTube|8kZ4x3-oogY|Raw Video: Yemeni Forces Open Fire on Protesters}}
  +
}}
In January 2011, shortly after the [[Tunisian revolution|popular ouster]] of the [[Tunisia]]n government, major street protests materialized in [[Sana'a]], the Yemeni capital, to demand governmental changes.<ref name="NADA BAKRI">{{registration required|date=May 2011}} {{cite news| author = Bakri, Nada| url = http://www.nytimes.com/2011/01/28/world/middleeast/28yemen.html| title = Thousands in Yemen Protest Against the Government| work = [[The New York Times]]| date = 27 January 2011 | accessdate = 27 January 2011}}</ref> Protests spread to the traditionally restive south, with particularly aggressive protests in cities like [[Aden]] and [[Ta'izz]].<ref name="NADA BAKRI" /> Initially, demonstrators protested against a plan to amend the [[constitution of Yemen|constitution]] and over the country's sluggish economy and high jobless rates.<ref name="afreuters">{{cite news | author = Ghobari, Mohammed; Sudam, Mohamed | title = Update 1 – Protests Erupt in Yemen, President Offers Reform | date = 20 January 2011 | publisher = Reuters | url = http://af.reuters.com/article/tunisiaNews/idAFLDE70J2BZ20110120?sp=true | accessdate = 14 May 2011 |archiveurl = http://www.webcitation.org/5vt1YRykA |archivedate = 20 January 2011 |deadurl=no }}</ref> However, protests grew larger by late January and took on an increasingly pointed tone of criticism toward President [[Ali Abdullah Saleh]], with many demonstrators beginning to call openly for new leadership in Yemen.<ref name="Irish Times breaking26">{{cite news| url = http://www.irishtimes.com/newspaper/breaking/2011/0127/breaking26.html| title = Yemenis in Anti-President Protest| author = Staff | publisher = Reuters (via ''[[The Irish Times]]'')| date = 27 January 2011 | accessdate = 14 May 2011}}</ref> including at least 10,000 at Sana'a University.<ref name="Irish Times breaking26" /><ref name="tom finn">{{cite news| url = http://www.guardian.co.uk/world/2011/jan/27/yemen-protests-president-saleh| title = Yemenis Take to the Streets Calling for President Saleh To Step Down – As Unemployment rises and Oil and Water Reserves Dwindle, Thousands Demand an End to President's 32-Year Reign| author = Finn, Tom | work = [[The Guardian]]| date = 27 January 2011 | accessdate = 14 May 2011}}</ref>
In January 2011, shortly after the [[Tunisian revolution|popular ouster]] of the [[Tunisia]]n government, major street protests materialized in [[Sana'a]], the Yemeni capital, to demand governmental changes.<ref name="NADA BAKRI">{{registration required|date=May 2011}} {{cite news| author = Bakri, Nada| url = http://www.nytimes.com/2011/01/28/world/middleeast/28yemen.html| title = Thousands in Yemen Protest Against the Government| work = [[The New York Times]]| date = 27 January 2011 | accessdate = 27 January 2011}}</ref> Protests spread to the traditionally restive south, with particularly aggressive protests in cities like [[Aden]] and [[Ta'izz]].<ref name="NADA BAKRI" /> Initially, demonstrators protested against a plan to amend the [[constitution of Yemen|constitution]] and over the country's sluggish economy and high jobless rates.<ref name="afreuters">{{cite news | author = Ghobari, Mohammed; Sudam, Mohamed | title = Update 1 – Protests Erupt in Yemen, President Offers Reform | date = 20 January 2011 | publisher = Reuters | url = http://af.reuters.com/article/tunisiaNews/idAFLDE70J2BZ20110120?sp=true | accessdate = 14 May 2011 |archiveurl = http://www.webcitation.org/5vt1YRykA |archivedate = 20 January 2011 |deadurl=no }}</ref> However, protests grew larger by late January and took on an increasingly pointed tone of criticism toward President [[Ali Abdullah Saleh]], with many demonstrators beginning to call openly for new leadership in Yemen.<ref name="Irish Times breaking26">{{cite news| url = http://www.irishtimes.com/newspaper/breaking/2011/0127/breaking26.html| title = Yemenis in Anti-President Protest| author = Staff | publisher = Reuters (via ''[[The Irish Times]]'')| date = 27 January 2011 | accessdate = 14 May 2011}}</ref> including at least 10,000 at Sana'a University.<ref name="Irish Times breaking26" /><ref name="tom finn">{{cite news| url = http://www.guardian.co.uk/world/2011/jan/27/yemen-protests-president-saleh| title = Yemenis Take to the Streets Calling for President Saleh To Step Down – As Unemployment rises and Oil and Water Reserves Dwindle, Thousands Demand an End to President's 32-Year Reign| author = Finn, Tom | work = [[The Guardian]]| date = 27 January 2011 | accessdate = 14 May 2011}}</ref>
By February, opposition leader [[Tawakel Karman]] called for a "Day of Rage" in the mold of mass nationwide demonstrations that helped to topple the government of Tunisia and [[2011 Egyptian revolution|put pressure]] on the government of President [[Hosni Mubarak]] in [[Egypt]].<ref name="Feb3_DayRage_aljaz">{{cite news | author = Staff | title = New Protests Erupt in Yemen – Activists Calling for the Ouster of President Clash with Government Supporters in Sanaa | date=29 January 2011 | publisher = [[Al Jazeera English]] | url = http://english.aljazeera.net/news/middleeast/2011/01/2011129112626339573.html | accessdate=29 April 2011 | archiveurl = http://www.webcitation.org/5w8S9MZ1r |archivedate=30 January 2011 |deadurl=no }}</ref> The protest drew more than 20,000 participants, as well as a show of force from Saleh's supporters.<ref name="bbc_20k">{{cite news | author = Staff | url = http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-middle-east-12353479 | title = Yemen Protests: 20,000 Call for President Saleh To Go | publisher = BBC News | date = 29 January 2011 |accessdate = 29 April 2011}}</ref><ref name="oneindia_armedGPC_progov">{{cite web | author = Staff | url = http://news.oneindia.in/2011/02/03/salehpartisans-take-over-yemen-protestsite-aid0126.html | title = Saleh Partisans Take Over Yemen Protest Site | publisher = [[Agence France-Presse]] (via [[oneindia.in]]) | date=3 February 2011 | accessdate=29 April 2011}}</ref> Security forces responded to protests in Aden with live ammunition and [[tear gas]].<ref name="aljaz_aden">{{cite web | author = Staff | url = http://english.aljazeera.net/news/middleeast/2011/02/201123105140512715.html |title = Opposing Protesters Rally in Yemen – Anti-Government Demonstrators Reiterate Calls for President To Stand Down While His Supporters Stage a Counter Rally | publisher = [[Al Jazeera English]] | date=3 February 2011 | accessdate=29 April 2011}}</ref> After Mubarak quit power in Egypt, demonstrators celebrating the revolution and calling for a similar uprising in Yemen were attacked by police and pro-Saleh tribesmen.<ref>{{cite web | author = Staff | url = http://english.aljazeera.net/news/middleeast/2011/02/201121211858966496.html | title = Thousands Rally Across Yemen – Several Injured as Protesters Clash with Police on Fourth Straight Day of Demonstrations in Capital and Country's South | publisher = [[Al Jazeera English]] |date=14 February 2011 | accessdate=30 April 2011}}</ref> [[Cleric]]s called for a [[national unity government]] and elections to be held in six months in an effort to quell violence and place members of the opposition in government.<ref>{{cite web | url = http://english.aljazeera.net/news/middleeast/2011/02/2011217991104240.html | title = Yemen Clerics Urge Unity Government – Influential Group of Clerics Demand Transitional Unity Government, as Two Demonstrators Are Shot in Continuing Violence | author = Staff | date = 18 February 2011 | publisher = [[Al-Jazeera English]] | accessdate = 30 April 2011}}</ref> Later in the month, deaths were reported in Ta'izz and Aden after security forces attacked protesters with lethal force.<ref>{{cite news | author = Staff | url = http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-middle-east-12507889 | title = Yemen Protests: Five Killed at Anti-Government Rallies | publisher = BBC News | date = 18 February 2011 | accessdate = 30 April 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite news | author = Staff | url = http://english.aljazeera.net/news/middleeast/2011/02/2011218111854417798.html | title = Yemen Observes 'Friday of Fury' – At Least Six People Killed as Tens of Thousands of Protesters, Both Pro- and Anti-Government, March in Several Cities | publisher = [[Al-Jazeera English]] | date=18 February 2011 | accessdate=30 April 2011}}</ref> By the end of February, several major tribes in Yemen had joined the anti-government protests and protests swelled in size to well over 100,000 on several days.<ref>{{cite web | author = Staff | url = http://www.presstv.ir/detail/167110.html | title = Major Tribes Join Yemen Protests | publisher = [[Press TV]] | date = 26 February 2011 | accessdate = 5 May 2011}}</ref> Saleh also called for a national unity government, but opposition leaders rejected the proposal and called for Saleh to step down immediately.<ref>{{cite news | author = Staff | url = http://english.aljazeera.net/news/middleeast/2011/02/2011228204148506367.html | title = Yemen Opposition Rejects Unity Deal – President Ali Abdullah Saleh's Offer To Form National Unity Government Is Dubbed Outdated 'Tranquilisers' | publisher = [[Al Jazeera English]] | date = 28 February 2011 | accessdate = 5 May 2011}}</ref>
By February, opposition leader [[Tawakel Karman]] called for a "Day of Rage" in the mold of mass nationwide demonstrations that helped to topple the government of Tunisia and [[2011 Egyptian Tribes Join Yemen Protests | publisher = [[Press TV]] | date = 26 February 2011 | accessdate = 5 May 2011}}</ref> Saleh also called for a national unity government, but opposition leaders rejected the proposal and called for Saleh to step down immediately.<ref>{{cite news | author = Staff | url = http://english.aljazeera.net/news/middleeast/2011/02/2011228204148506367.html | title = Yemen Opposition Rejects Unity Deal – President Ali Abdullah Saleh's Offer To Form National Unity Government Is Dubbed Outdated 'Tranquilisers' | publisher = [[Al Jazeera English]] | date = 28 February 2011 | accessdate = 5 May 2011}}</ref>

{{wikinews|45 killed after Yemen protesters fired upon}}
 
In March, opposition groups presented a proposal that would see Saleh leave power peacefully,<ref>{{cite web | author = Staff | url = http://www.mysinchew.com/node/54144 | title = Yemen Opposition, Clerics Offer Saleh Smooth Exit | publisher = [[Agence France-Presse]] (via ''[[Sin Chew Daily]]'') | date = 3 March 2011 | accessdate = 18 May 2011}}</ref><ref>{{registration required|date=May 2011}} {{cite news | url = http://www.ft.com/cms/s/0/27989d86-4513-11e0-80e7-00144feab49a.html | title = Yemeni Proposition Offers Saleh a Transition Plan | work = [[Financial Times]] | date = 2 March 2011 | accessdate = 11 March 2011}}</ref> but Saleh refused to accept it.<ref>{{cite news | author = Staff | title = Yemen Rallies Grow; Saleh Rejects Transition Plan | url = http://www.rferl.org/content/yemen_protests/2328432.html | publisher = Reuters (via [[Radio Free Europe/Radio Liberty]]) | date = 4 March 2011 | accessdate = 18 May 2011}}</ref> A number of prominent Yemeni government officials resigned over the violence used to disperse protests.<ref>{{cite news | author = Staff | title = Yemen MPs Quit Ruling Party – Several Members of General People's Congress Resign in Protest Against Violence Used Against Anti-Government Protesters | publisher = [[Al-Jazeera English]] | url = http://english.aljazeera.net/news/middleeast/2011/03/20113514455840795.html | date = 5 March 2011 | accessdate = 20 May 2011}}</ref> On 18 March, 45 protesters were shot dead in Sana'a,<ref>{{cite news | author = Staff | title = Yemen Unrest: 'Dozens Killed' as Gunmen Target Rally | url = http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/mobile/world-middle-east-12783585?SThisFB | accessdate = 18 March 2011 | publisher = BBC News | date = 18 March 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite news | author = Staff | title = Doctors in Yemen Have Told the BBC That Unidentified Gunmen Fired on an Anti-Government Rally in the Capital, Sanaa | url = http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/mobile/world-middle-east-12789220 | accessdate = 18 March 2011 | publisher = BBC News | date = 18 March 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite news | url = http://www.guardian.co.uk/world/2011/mar/18/yemen-police-massacre-45-protesters | title = 45 Protesters Killed in Yemen | accessdate = 19 March 2011 | date = 18 March 2011 | work = [[The Guardian]] | archiveurl = http://www.webcitation.org/5xIpRum44 | archivedate = 19 March 2011 | author = Finn, Tom}}</ref><ref name="autogenerated1">{{cite news | author = | title = Yemen Forces 'Open Fire on Protesters' | url = http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-middle-east-12783585 | publisher = BBC News | date = 18 March 2011 | accessdate = 18 March 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite news | author = Al-Azak, Mohamed; Qiuyun, Wang | title = 41 Dead, 200 Injured as Yemen Police Shoot at Protesters | url = http://news.xinhuanet.com/english2010/world/2011-03/18/c_13786700.htm | accessdate = 18 March 2011 | newspaper = Xinhua| date = 18 March 2011}}</ref> an incident that prompted the declaration of a state of emergency<ref name="autogenerated1"/> and international condemnation.<ref name="wpost18march">{{cite news | author = Almasmar, Hakim | title = Yemen Imposes State of Emergency after Deadly Attack on Protesters | url = http://www.washingtonpost.com/world/protesters-killed-in-yemens-capital-by/2011/03/18/ABFd2hp_story.html | accessdate = 19 March 2011 | work = [[The Washington Post]] | date = 18 March 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite news | title = France Strongly Condemns Yemen Attack on Protesters | url = http://www.reuters.com/article/2011/03/18/yemen-france-idUSPISIEE78520110318 | accessdate = 19 March 2011 | publisher = Reuters | date = 18 March 2011 | author = Love, Brian}}</ref> Several days later, Saleh indicated that he would be willing to leave power by the end of the year or even sooner,<ref>{{cite news | author = | url = http://www.ctv.ca/CTVNews/World/20110322/yemen-saleh-out-by-year-end-110322/ | title = Yemen Leader Says Ready To Step Down by Year-End | publisher = [[CTV News Channel (Canada)|CTV News]] | date = 22 March 2011 | accessdate = 22 March 2011 }}</ref><ref>{{cite news | author = Jamjoom, Mohammed | url = http://edition.cnn.com/2011/WORLD/meast/03/23/yemen.protests/index.html | title = Yemen's Leader Says He Will Accept Transition Plan | publisher = CNN | date = 23 March 2011 | accessdate = 25 March 2011}}</ref> but he later affirmed that he would not step down.<ref name=aje0325>{{cite news | author = | title = Thousands in Yemen March Against Saleh | url = http://english.aljazeera.net/news/middleeast/2011/03/201132511732578174.html | accessdate = 25 March 2011 | publisher = [[Al Jazeera English]] | date = 25 March 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite news | author = | title = I Can't Quit, Says Yemen Leader | url = http://www.google.com/hostednews/ukpress/article/ALeqM5i0TETypz8_hEMkbRK_bibXB4UTJQ?docId=N0211441301031249982A | accessdate = 25 March 2011 | date = 25 March 2011 | publisher = Associated Press (via [[UKPA]])}}</ref><ref>{{cite news | author = | title = In Yemen, a Day of Rival Demonstrations | url = http://edition.cnn.com/2011/WORLD/meast/03/25/yemen.unrest/ | accessdate = 25 March 2011 | publisher = CNN | date = 25 March 2011}}</ref> By the end of March, six of Yemen's 18 [[administrative divisions of Yemen|governorates]] were out of the government's control, officials said.<ref>{{cite news | author = | title = Yemen Govt Loses Control of Six of the 18 Provinces | url = http://www.hindustantimes.com/Yemen-govt-loses-control-of-six-of-the-18-provinces/Article1-679119.aspx | accessdate = 29 March 2011 | publisher = [[Press Trust of India]] (via ''[[Hindustan Times]]'') | date = 29 March 2011}}</ref>
In March, opposition groups presented a proposal that would see Saleh leave power peacefully,<ref>{{cite web | author = Staff | url = http://www.mysinchew.com/node/54144 | title = Yemen Opposition, Clerics Offer Saleh Smooth Exit | publisher = [[Agence France-Presse]] (via ''[[Sin Chew Daily]]'') | date = 3 March 2011 | accessdate = 18 May 2011}}</ref><ref>{{registration required|date=May 2011}} accessdate = 11 March 2011}}</ref> but Saleh refused to accept it.<ref>{{cite news | author = Staff | title = Yemen Rallies Grow; Saleh Rejects Transition Plan | url =
